awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Giant Icebergs and Their Decay
awd_abstract_narration:
Icebergs are a component of the Antarctic climate system, yet a comprehensive representation of their dynamics in climate models has remained elusive. Representing the role of icebergs in global climate models (GCMs) poses a formidable challenge to the scientific community. The most striking shortcoming of current iceberg models is arguably that they do not represent giant tabular icebergs, even though giant icebergs carry most of the freshwater stored in icebergs in the Southern Ocean. This lack of large icebergs in models is mostly due to the difficulties associated with adequately modeling iceberg decay. In particular, fracturing and breakup are not typically considered in iceberg models, despite being dominant iceberg decay processes. 

Investigators are to address these issues using a hierarchy of iceberg models, ranging from an idealized analytical model to a comprehensive GCM, in concert with recent observational data. The main objective of this study is to develop a new iceberg model that:
(i) accounts for iceberg breakup and fracturing processes that have been neglected to date,
(ii) improves on the representation of iceberg decay processes that were considered in previous models,
(iii) explicitly represents large tabular icebergs.

The primary broader impact of the proposed work will be through a K-12 teacher workshop series showcasing this project as an example of how scientists develop physical models. Ongoing changes in the California K-12 science standards will enable the teachers to creatively use this material in their classrooms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Icebergs are made of fresh water. When icebergs melt in the ocean they change the salinity of the sea water near the surface. The freshening of surface seawater can affect how readily sea-ice forms in winter as well as change the ocean currents. Therefore, where icebergs drift to, and how they melt and decay, matters when we simulate the ocean circulation and climate system. Climate models have recently started to include a representation of icebergs. The icebergs are approximated as tiny point particles that carry frozen fresh water, drift depending on the ocean currents and surface winds, and melt following some simple rules depending on surface waves and ocean surface temperature. Prior to this work, an important process of iceberg decay was missing from the climate models: the "footloose" mechanism involves surface waves lapping at the iceberg edge, melting them at the waterline. Ice above the water line falls off the cliff leaving a submerged foot. Since ice is more buoyant than water the foot bends and eventually breaks off. In this work, the footloose process was added to the climate model representation of icebergs. This allowed the model to use a more realistic distribution of iceberg sizes (larger than previously used) and for the eventual distribution of iceberg melt water to be more realistic (Fig.1).

Climate models to date have only represented icebergs upto a certain size, typically a few kilometers in width. Most of the ice that comes from Antarctica is in the form of much bigger tabular icebergs, sometimes 100?s of kilometers across. We developed new capabilities in the iceberg model that paves the way to including these giant tabular icebergs in climate simulations. We demonstrate the new capabilities by simulating a real tabular iceberg known as A68a. This iceberg drifted near to South Georgia in the Atlantic Ocean, where it was observed to break twice. In our simulations we show the first break up occurred when the iceberg collides with a seamount. The second break up is of great interest because it happens far from any seamounts or coastlines. Through this work we discovered a new trigger of breakup in which the large scale ocean currents effectively tore the iceberg in two (Fig. 2).
